title: [$250] Clarify Approval Options When Held Expenses Exist

labels.name: External
labels.description: Added to denote the issue can be worked on by a contributor

labels.name: Daily
labels.description: KSv2

labels.name: NewFeature
labels.description: Something to build that is a new item.

labels.name: Help Wanted
labels.description: Apply this label when an issue is open to proposals by contributors

body:
If you havenâ€™t already, check out our [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/Expensify/ReactNativeChat/blob/main/contributingGuides/CONTRIBUTING.md) for onboarding and email contributors@expensify.com to request to join our Slack channel! ___ **Version Number:** v9.2.12-1 **Reproducible in staging?:** Y **Reproducible in production?:** Y **If this was caught during regression testing, add the test name, ID and link from TestRail:** N/A New Feature **Email or phone of affected tester (no customers):** ted@expensify.com **Logs:** N/A **Expensify/Expensify Issue URL:** N/A **Issue reported by:** @twisterdotcom **Slack conversation** (hyperlinked to channel name): [#product](https://expensify.slack.com/archives/C03U7DCU4/p1757509841450259) ## Action Performed: 1. Open an expense report containing both compliant and held expenses. 2. Observe the "Approve" button at the top of the report. 3. Click the "Approve" button. 4. A modal appears prompting the user to choose between approving only unheld expenses or approving the entire report. ## Expected Result: When held expenses exist, the approval flow should make the two approval options clear **before** clicking "Approve." The user should not see a misleading single total on the main button. Instead, the button should explicitly allow the user to choose between: - Approve only unheld expenses (with correct amount shown) - Approve all expenses (with correct amount shown) ## Actual Result: The "Approve" button always shows the full report total even if some expenses are held. Only after clicking does a modal appear, forcing the user to choose. This creates confusion, as the primary action does not align with the amounts shown. ## Workaround: Users can still approve reports by making a selection in the modal, but the flow is unclear and can cause hesitation or mistakes. ## Platforms: Select the officially supported platforms where the issue was reproduced: - [x] Android: App - [x] Android: mWeb Chrome - [x] iOS: App - [x] iOS: mWeb Safari - [x] iOS: mWeb Chrome - [x] Windows: Chrome - [x] MacOS: Chrome / Safari - [x] MacOS: Desktop ## Screenshots/Videos https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0b8d23a3-ae0e-4e41-b6f3-c53587a892b2 - Demonstrates how the modal appears after clicking "Approve," requiring the user to choose between two totals. [View all open jobs on GitHub](https://github.com/Expensify/App/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3A%22Help+Wanted%22) cc @shawnborton, @JmillsExpensify, @puneetlath, @dubielzyk-expensify.

title: [$250] Clean up report page styles

labels.name: External
labels.description: Added to denote the issue can be worked on by a contributor

labels.name: Daily
labels.description: KSv2

labels.name: NewFeature
labels.description: Something to build that is a new item.

labels.name: Help Wanted
labels.description: Apply this label when an issue is open to proposals by contributors

body:
Now that we have collapsible rows on the Reports page, we want to take a moment to clean up some of the styles. Right now, especially on mobile, the table style feels quite heavy and unbalanced: So we'd like to adjust some styles to: - use a consistent normal text weight for titles and totals - on mobile, reduce the size of the From/To avatar, reduce the font weight, and make it so that the From/To is at the top of the row - use an "extra small" button size on mobile - this will bring the buttons from 28px -> 20px tall The result is this: https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d9d2b979-755d-4a42-81d2-240e1f1632c1 More in depth mocks for posterity: cc @Expensify/design to make sure we're good with the above changes, cc @Expensify/product-pr for extra eyes too

title: [$250] Remove SearchContext from the useOnyx when not needed

labels.name: Reviewing
labels.description: Has a PR in review

labels.name: External
labels.description: Added to denote the issue can be worked on by a contributor

labels.name: Weekly
labels.description: KSv2

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Something is broken. Auto assigns a BugZero manager.

labels.name: AutoAssignerNewDotQuality
labels.description: Used to assign quality issues to engineers

body:
Coming from [this proposal](https://expensify.slack.com/archives/C05LX9D6E07/p1757511640708319) ### Background The useOnyx hook (a wrapper around the original useOnyx) is used throughout the app. Inside it, we subscribe to SearchContext so the hook can return data from either the regular Onyx keys or the special SNAPSHOT keys (which are specifically designed for the Reports page). However, useOnyx hooks that are not used on the Reports page donâ€™t need SearchContext, since they donâ€™t rely on currentSearchHash (which is only used to access the current SNAPSHOT data). ### Problem If SearchContext changes, then every useOnyx in the App will rerender. Such context change will trigger rerenders in screens that are rendered in the history, preloaded screens or modals that live outside of navigation like SearchRouter and can cause massive overhead. ### Solution Avoid useOnyx calls outside the Reports/Search tree from subscribing to SearchContext. How: SearchContext provides components with isOnSearch prop that with the help of SearchScopeProvider tells us if the useOnyx is part of Search/index component tree(is on Reports page). To reduce rerenders, we could: - take isOnSearch prop out of SearchContext and put it in SearchScopeProvider , isOnSearch doesn't trigger rerenders as it is a static prop. - in useOnyx use the new use API to conditionally listen to SearchContext, that way useOnyx hooks that are part of Search/index component tree(this is static) will access SearchContext that they need and useOnyx hooks that don't need it won't rerender. ``` const useOnyx: OriginalUseOnyx = >(key: TKey, options?: UseOnyxOptions, dependencies?: DependencyList) => { const {isOnSearch} = useIsOnSearch(); let currentSearchHash: number | undefined; if (isOnSearch) { const {currentSearchHash: searchContextCurrentSearchHash} = use(SearchContext); currentSearchHash = searchContextCurrentSearchHash; } ... rest of useOnyx hook ... ``` Benefits This will provide big boost to scenarios where SearchContext changes, examples(perf measured on iOS simulator): 1. On Reports page the user changes search type with the search type menu(Submit -> Pay): - OLD: total React work: 7234.014ms - ~55 commits - NEW: total React work: 5357.51 - 48 commits (25%/1877 ms better) 3. After fresh log into the app, user enters Reports page and then goes back to Inbox: - OLD: total React work: 5992.427ms - ~67 commits - NEW: total React work: 4890.688 - 59 commits (18%/1102 ms better)

  • Upwork Job ID: 1965843867509223663
  • Last Price Increase: 2025-09-10

title: [$250] Add extra logs to the useSidebarOrderedReports hook

labels.name: Reviewing
labels.description: Has a PR in review

labels.name: External
labels.description: Added to denote the issue can be worked on by a contributor

labels.name: Weekly
labels.description: KSv2

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Something is broken. Auto assigns a BugZero manager.

body:
Coming from [here](https://expensify.slack.com/archives/C05LX9D6E07/p1757427870254749?thread_ts=1756201512.926039&cid=C05LX9D6E07) ### Background The useSidebarOrderedReports hook manages and sorts reports data. It processes large amounts of information, including chat reports, policies, and transactions. The hook includes a logChangedDeps function that tracks dependency changes and logs performance metrics. ### Problem The current measurement only captures the logging overhead via processingDuration, not the actual data processing time. As a result, we lack visibility into how expensive this hook is during renders, making it difficult to detect or diagnose performance regressions. ### Solution Enhance the logging in useSidebarOrderedReports by: - Measuring the actual execution time of the hookâ€™s data processing logic. - Tracking component usage alongside corresponding render durations.

title: [$250] Forbid inline useOnyx selectors

labels.name: Reviewing
labels.description: Has a PR in review

labels.name: External
labels.description: Added to denote the issue can be worked on by a contributor

labels.name: Weekly
labels.description: KSv2

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Something is broken. Auto assigns a BugZero manager.

labels.name: AutoAssignerNewDotQuality
labels.description: Used to assign quality issues to engineers

body:
coming from [this proposal](https://expensify.slack.com/archives/C05LX9D6E07/p1757428589519799) ### Background Selectors in react-native-onyx are functions that allow to subscribe a subset of data from storage, providing performance benefits by only re-rendering components when the selected data changes, rather than when any property in the entire object changes. They transform, filter, or extract specific data and support type-safe operations on both individual keys and collections. Recently we merged a couple of improvements to useOnyx, including the memoization working properly with stable references. However, most of our codebase still uses inline selectors, which prevents us from taking advantage of these optimizations. ### Problem When using selectors in useOnyx, if you define the selector as inline function directly in the options object, then the memoization system breaks causing unnecessary re-computations and re-renders on every component update. ### Solution Make selectors first-class citizens in E/App by organizing them according to their usage scope: - Shared selectors: if a selector is reused across multiple components, define it in a dedicated selectors/ directory so it can be consistently imported and reused. - Local selectors: if a selector exists purely for the needs of a single component or hook, define it in the same file outside the component where itâ€™s used to avoid unnecessary abstraction. - Contextual selectors: if a selector relies on additional data from the component itself, define it as a useCallback inside the component, with the relevant data passed as dependencies.
